titleStmt.title: James Donaho to James F. Robinson
CWG9008

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p:
To his Excellency James F. Robinson
Govenor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner, James Donahoe, would most respectfully submit the following statement of facts. At the February term 1862 of the Fayette Circuit Court, two judgments were rendered against him, one for $300 & the other for $150. The one judgment was rendered upon the charge of keeping a disorderly House, and the other for suffering gaming. The last indictment was sustained by a witness of great prejudices against petitioner, and your petitioner knows said witness' statement to have been false in every respect.
By the remission of the foregoing fines your Petitioner will ever pray &c.
The undersigned would request the remission of foregoing fines, believing, as they do, that James Donahoe has abandoned the grocery business & is a quiet & peacible citizen.

Chas J. Bradley
Sheriff
Jno. C. Hansbro
Speed J. Goodloe
H, G, Williams
R Cox
C D Carr
Thos Sadler
C T Worley
E Brennan
J. B Norton C F C C
H. T. Duncan Jr
Tho J. Nichols
Deputy Sheriff
Z. Gibbons
J. H. Harrison
John B Payne Jr.
Thos. D Carr
W H Lusby
R, D, Malone
Hunter N Band
John T. Miller
J B Wilgus & Co

Fayette Cir Ct
Jas. Donahue Pettn to remit fines
$300
$150
The two fines are remitted except Twenty five dollars & costs in each case
